Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant: The Cultural Politics and Bioethics of Reproductive Surgery in Mexico, 1800-1940

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Audience Summary

This dissertation research project is in the history of science; it focuses on reproductive surgery in Mexico with a particular emphasis on the politics of cesarean sections and sterilizing operations. The project explores religious, state, and scientific debates and their relations to the development of clinical operations. It will address how reproductive surgeries acquire racial and religious concerns, and under what circumstances these concerns shift or persist. It will draw on a range of archival sources, including hospital registers, medical records, prison reports, newspaper articles, and letters from doctors, midwives, patients, and medical students. It will link a range of themes and actors to investigate the factors that influenced clinical decisions and how they affected the lives patients. The investigator (the Co-PI) will also develop a historical database of information about public client demographics, surgical technologies, and patient complaints regarding reproductive surgeries in Mexico. She will develop this data in coordination with the Mexican Secretary of Health's project on maternal healthcare, and she will make the information available to lawmakers, international NGOs, and advocacy groups.

Technical Summary

The intellectual merit of the project is based in the approach to the history science that gives priority to long-term historical structures over events. The historical range begins in the late colonial period. Doing so will allow the investigator to fully establish and explore the key theme: State, Church, and popular conflicts over defining and managing bodies and souls in birth (and in death). The project will utilize documents that illuminate the connections between surgical technologies, childbirth, and religious and spiritual worldviews. Doing so will facilitate an analysis of two important themes: the social construction of race in medical practice, and the role of religion in both shaping and reacting to scientific ideologies. The project aims to develop and to engage with original historical and philosophical frameworks for analyzing reproductive surgeries; as a result, it has the potential to modify how historians think about the global history of obstetrics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the assistance of the NSF DDRIG, Elizabeth O’Brien (PhD Candidate in the Department of History at the University of Texas at Austin), conducted twelve additional months of archival research for her doctoral dissertation. The project aims to write a cultural history of sexual reproduction in Mexico with a particular emphasis on the politics of surgical operations. First, the the study demonstrates that religious, racial, and gender ideologies have influenced the development and implementation of surgical technologies since the late colonial period in the Americas. Second, the thesis seeks to write this history over the long term so as to achieve a processual view of how medical practice has been shaped by different forces. Third, the research recovers popular attitudes about reproduction by analyzing common people’s reactions to medical and political mandates. By analyzing the cultural history of reproduction and surgery, this dissertation offers an innovative lens through which to study Mexican history; at the same time, each chapter provides an original contribution to the history of medicine. The researcher dedicated the first six months of the grant period to consulting documents in the state of Veracruz in Mexico. She then spent one month conducting research in the Huntington Library in Pasadena California, followed by two months in the historical archive of the Secretary of Health in Mexico City. Finally, the researcher spent three months performing research in New York at the Rockefeller Archive Center.

This doctoral research is the first English language book-length project that seeks to uncover the historical roots of obstetrical violence and forced sterilizations in Mexico. These problems are pertinent in contemporary politics and society: In 2012, for example, the Mexican Ministry of Internal Affairs reported that among indigenous women who underwent medical sterilization, 27 percent did not consent to the procedure (this figure is based on nationwide data collected between 2006 and 2011). In 2012, the Mexican Ministry of Internal Affairs reported that among indigenous women who underwent medical sterilization, 27 percent did not consent to the procedure (this statistic is based on nationwide data collected between 2006 and 2011). In a follow-up study, leading researchers revealed that eighty percent of indigenous women in Mexico are victims of obstetrical violence. Even state authorities have declared that these statistics represent a crisis in maternal healthcare, and the topic has attracted much NGO and media attention. Mexico is now the first nation in which cases of obstetrical violence have been brought to the Inter­American Commission on Human Rights (IACHR). To date, eight of these cases have been tried, and in each, the IACHR has ordered ‘restorative justice’— measures that provide financial compensation for the victims, including educational funds for their children. In addition, non repetition measures have been negotiated by NGOs with State Health Ministry of Mexico, although the State Health Ministry has still not implemented the majority of these agreed upon measures. The dissertation research, then, feeds into a political debate that is resulting in law changes and resource allocation. Although the dissertation research is a minor, scholarly contribution, this debate is prominent in Mexican society and there is a decided lack of historical information about its context.

The data collected during the DDRIG research period has been disseminated by means of ten public talks and invited lectures during 2015 and 2016. The DDRIG has also aided in the production of one article, which has been submitted for publication in a peer reviewed journal. More immediately, the researcher’s analysis and conclusions have been incorporated into the curricula used to train medical doctors at Mexico’s national university. The program, which respond to calls for humanities training for medical doctors, seeks to motivate doctors to consider the historical context and societal prejudices related to the treatments they utilize. The study will also join a body of literature that encourages the Mexican government to provide better funding for public hospitals and allow more time for patient consultation in public clinics. The DDRIG has thus supported a project that offers a cultural and historical, as well as empirical, examination of these issues, and because obstetrical violence and forced sterilization are sources of concern throughout the world, much of the analysis will be of interest to other nations. Thus, the project’s outcomes include educating the public on the factors that contribute to obstetrical violence, and urging citizens to consider the interface between cultural politics and surgical operations.
